keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon broke in September 2025, resulting in at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries.
The cable did not meet the certification or operational specifications set by the operator, CARRIS.

The preliminary report from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identifies serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were marked as completed even when not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as 'compliant and accepted'.
Eyewitnesses described the crash as chaotic, with one man named Bruno reporting the car behaving like a toy and a loud bang followed by a cloud of brown smoke.
The interim findings are preliminary and not conclusive; a final report is scheduled for release next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fatal crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, killed at least 16 people and injured several others after a steel cable snapped during operation. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet certification or operator (CARRIS) specifications, and there were serious deficiencies in maintenance practices, including falsified records of completed tasks. Eyewitnesses described the crash as chaotic and sudden, with one man named Bruno reporting the car behaving erratically. While the interim report is not conclusive, it raises significant concerns about safety standards and oversight in public transport infrastructure, with a final report expected next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
